bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Siler, September 19, 1952

div1.p: Hench informs Siler that he has not heard from Nogueira for over a month and is concerned the park will be dedicated with a different name. He regrets that he will be unable to attend the dedication or a fall meeting of the Walter Reed Memorial Association as he has used up all his vacation and meeting time. He does intend to have a report on the Camp Lazear dedication to present to the Association.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Siler, September 19, 1952
div1.opener:
September 19, 1952
Colonel J. F. Siler
Gorgas Memorial Institute
1835 Eye Street N.W.
Washington 6, D. C.
My dear Colonel Siler:
div1.p:
Thank you very kindly for your letter of September 15. Yes, I did hear
from General Love and have sent to Doctor Nogueira in Havana the names
of the officers, hoping that those who are to dedicate Lazear Park would
send them an invitation to the dedication.

Incidentally, I have not heard from Doctor Nogueira now for over a month
and I am greatly concerned lest his silence be due to the fact that he
has not been able to get his colleagues to go along with him in the matter
of the proper naming of the park. I hardly know what to do now. Perhaps,
as I have suspected all along, the construction of the Park has not gone
far enough for it to be dedicated. Perhaps the delay represents the
“normal Cuban manena.” Anyhow, I am writing him again today. If I don't
hear within a very few days, I will cable him and if I still don't hear, I
will have to play my last card; namely, notify four or five prominent
Cubans and Americans of the situation and ask them to make quiet inquiries
and suggestions that the park not be dedicated with the wrong name.

Most regretfully, I cannot attend the dedication. I did not know until
early this spring that they were planning to dedicate it this fall and
their plans, as outlined to me, were very vague. Unfortunately I have
been under the necessity of traveling so much this year that I have not
only used up all of my Clinic-allotted time for attendance at medical
meetings, but I will have used up all of my vacation time as I long ago
promised to go to a medical meeting in St. Louis on October 2 and another
one in Boston on October 29.

I have for weeks been trying to figure out how I could get to a meeting
of the Walter Reed Memorial Association this fall but I just don't see
how I can. Even if the Board of Managers were gracious enough to set the date
so that I could go enroute to Boston, I fear that I could not do it as I
simply do not have even an extra day's time left. I am particularly
anxious this year not to ask the Clinic for extra time as I must go to
Europe again next summer to attend an International Congress on Rheumatic
Diseases. The Clinic has sent me to Europe five times (three times within
the last four years), therefore I simply cannot ask them to sponsor or pay
for my 1953 European trip, which means that I must go and come entirely on
my vacation time.

Colonel Siler, I regret very much that I have not been able to attend a
meeting of the Walter Reed Memorial Association the last couple of years.
I am sure you are sympathetic with the special problems which have faced
me the last two years. I am glad to say that these responsibilities
are slackening a little bit and that I am learning to say “no” to numerous
invitations more frequently and more emphatically. I can assure you that
I am happy and indeed proud that I can be associated with the Board of
Managers and perhaps I will be forgiven for my absence and in lieu of
my presence, will stand the time that I have spent this year in the matter
of Lazear Park. I will certainly have for your Board a report of what has
gone on. Whether the report will be a happy one acknowledging the proper
actions of the Cubans or whether it will be an unhappy one reporting that
they have gone back on their word and that more work remains to be done
in the matter of correcting things remains to be seen. But it is a lot
easier to name the park correctly in the beginning than it would be to re-
name it once a false name had been established.

Some time ago I wrote to Doctor Nogueira sending him the information that
the Surgeon General or one of his associates would be delighted to receive
an invitation and that also the State Department, perhaps through the
American Embassy in Cuba, would be glad to participate. Whether or not
Doctor Nogueira has acted on this suggestion, I do not know.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
